case_vignette: A 33-year-old Black man presents to a dermatology clinic with a 5-month history of asymptomatic lesions on his arms and trunk! He is otherwise healthy with no personal or family history of skin disease! He has no history of fever, cough, shortness of breath, or joint pain! The patient has not tried any treatments for these lesions! On examination, there are several smooth, well-demarcated hypopigmented plaques on his upper arms and left flank! He has no similar lesions elsewhere on his body!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have smooth, light-colored patches on my upper arms and left side of my torso.
How long have you had these patches?
I've had these patches for about 5 months.
Do these patches itch or cause any pain?
No, the patches do not cause any pain or itching.
Have you noticed any similar patches on your skin in the past?
No, I have not noticed similar patches on my skin in the past.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin issues or any other skin diseases?
No, there is no family history of similar skin issues or other skin diseases.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you recently stopped taking any?
No, I have not tried any treatments for these lesions.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea Versicolor.
